definitions.definition: a meeting at which something, especially a new product or idea, or piece of work, is shown to a group of people

examples.text: The sales manager will **give a presentation** on the new products.
The conference will begin with a keynote presentation by a leading industry figure.

definitions.definition: the act of showing something or of giving something to somebody

examples.text: The trial was adjourned following the presentation of new evidence to the court.
The presentation of prizes began after the speeches.
The Mayor will **make the presentation** *(= hand over the gift)* herself.
Members will be admitted on presentation of a membership card.
a presentation copy *(= a free book given by the author or )*

definitions.definition: the way in which something is offered, shown, explained, etc. to others

examples.text: Improving the product's presentation *(= the way it is wrapped, advertised, etc.)* should increase sales.
I admire the clear, logical presentation of her arguments.
The main emphasis of the training will be on **presentation skills**.

definitions.definition: the series of computer slides (= images) that are shown with the talk when somebody gives a presentation at a meeting

examples.text: I've put my presentation on a memory stick.

definitions.definition: a ceremony or formal occasion during which a gift or prize is given
a performance of a play, etc. in a theatre
the position in which a baby is lying in the mother’s body just before birth

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin praesentatio(n-), from Latin praesentare ‘place before’ (in medieval Latin ‘present as a gift’), from praesent- ‘being at hand’, present participle of praeesse, from prae ‘before’ + esse ‘be’.
